1.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
1.text: Slaying as great an enemy of my people as Minsc would normally be a great victory, but he was just another puppet of the cult.

167.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
167.text: There was no honour in killing him while he did not know himself.

3.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
3.text: If you continue to make poor choices, we will soon have every god in this plane and the next hunting us.

396.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
396.text: You risk everything with this childish rebellion.

5.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
5.text: We have done Umberlee's will. Now let us never return to the depths of her domain again.
5.context: NodeContext: closing statement of a quest completed rather than a new adventure - the Umberlee section is done at this point, she's reflecting

7.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
7.text: Karlach is willing to become illithid so that we need not make that sacrifice. We should not stand in her way.
7.context: NodeContext: genuinely believes this to be true

8.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
8.text: Killing one's parents can be an important rite of passage - a usurpation of their place in society.
8.context: NodeContext: genuinely believes this to be true

388.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
388.text: Though she does not remember what she has done, the child Shadowheart became a proud woman today. And a strong leader.

9.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
9.text: My memories of this place are grim. The reality is worse.
9.context: NodeContext: horrified awe, in a mind flayer colony

12.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
12.text: That was horrendous. I would rather yank Tiamat's tail than travel beneath the water again.
12.context: NodeContext: TEE-uh-mat - dragon god. The party just travelled underwater, and Minthara HATED it.

360.speaker: Player
360.text: Don't tell me you're afraid of a little water.

286.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
286.text: I have something of a feline nature. I do not like getting wet, and I will gladly scratch out your eyes if you annoy me.

304.speaker: Player
304.text: Let's stay on dry land from now on.
304.context: NodeContext: ÆB-o-leth- large underwater abomination, familiar to Minthara

141.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
141.text: Agreed. Leave the waters to the fish and the aboleths.
141.context: NodeContext: ÆB-o-leth- large underwater abomination, familiar to Minthara

153.speaker: Player
153.text: That was exciting. Where's your sense of adventure?

393.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
393.text: My sense of self-preservation outmuscled it on this occasion.

13.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
13.text: I will gladly help Astarion to destroy his enemies, but I hope he does not expect me to call him Lord.

14.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
14.text: I only survived Orin's sadistic games because she allowed me to. Even if we find her soon, I doubt the child Yenna will be in one piece.

21.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
21.text: We have done Umberlee's will. Now let us stay far from the depths of her dread domain.
21.context: NodeContext: closing statement of a quest completed rather than a new adventure - the Umberlee section is done at this point, she's reflecting

22.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
22.text: We have done Umberlee's will. Now let us stay far from the depths of her dread domain.
22.context: NodeContext: closing statement of a quest completed rather than a new adventure - the Umberlee section is done at this point, she's reflecting

37.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
37.text: If we stop to talk, we will be food for the fish.

44.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
44.text: While she lives, Orin will continue to terrorise us, and soon she will make good on her threats. She thinks we are weak, afraid, vulnerable.

53.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
53.text: We need to prove her wrong.

45.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
45.text: Despite my antipathy toward Shar and her devotees, I feel honoured to fight alongside a Dark Justiciar. Their power is legendary.
45.context: NodeContext: having just killed the Chosen of a god - delighted and slightly in awe of what the party have achieved

57.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
57.text: Even the intervention of their gods can't save these chosen from our vengeance. We defy divinity.
57.context: NodeContext: having just killed the Chosen of a god - delighted and slightly in awe of what the party have achieved

63.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
63.text: We are unstoppable. I feel like we could conquer the hells.
63.context: NodeContext: delighted, having just slain a devil in his own home

67.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
67.text: We came here to find Ketheric and the Absolute, not Wyll's devil-mistress. We must press on.

68.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
68.text: This city has one too many self-righteous Ravengards. I would have preferred Wyll cut his family ties.

69.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
69.text: Our victory is at hand. We cannot falter now, no matter what is required of us.

84.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
84.text: I will fight alongside Minsc, but if he so much as refers to my butt, let alone attempts to kick it, I will skewer that damned hamster of his.
84.context: NodeContext: irritated - the 'butt' mention is a reference to Minsc talking of 'kicking butts' constantly

87.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
87.text: I am loathe to admit it, but if we can pacify Minsc he may be a worthy companion.
87.context: NodeContext: reluctant to admit a 'good guy' is a worthy ally

164.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
164.text: Any man who can resist being digested by a mimic may even give an elder brain food for thought.
164.context: NodeContext: impressed by Minsc's resilience - play on words with food and digested is intentional.

89.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
89.text: We cannot allow Gale to go through with Elminster's ludicrous plan. Destroying the Absolute before we fully understand it would be madness.
89.context: NodeContext: the 'plan' is for Gale to destroy the absolute - Minthara is dead set against this

93.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
93.text: The Orphic Hammer may be the key to our survival. I for one would be glad to avoid complete ceremorphosis.
93.context: NodeContext: warning - she's concerned about the player's behaviour

95.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
95.text: I have been watching you more closely than ever since the night we were forced to restrain you.
95.context: NodeContext: warning - she's concerned about the player's behaviour

279.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
279.text: I believe you have your urges under control, for now, and that you may become the master of them.
279.context: NodeContext: warning - she's concerned about the player's behaviour

324.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
324.text: But if you so much as think about harming me, I will pluck the thought from your mind, and then your heart from your chest.
324.context: NodeContext: warning, she's losing her patience with you

98.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
98.text: The gith god-queen is dreadful to behold. I understand now why you admire her.
98.context: NodeContext: has just found out Karlach is living on borrowed time - genuine concern

116.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
116.text: I am concerned for Karlach. She is strong, but even her courage may falter now that she knows how little time remains to her.
116.context: NodeContext: has just found out Karlach is living on borrowed time - genuine concern

160.speaker: Player
160.text: She won't give up as long as we support her.

345.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
345.text: Then that is what we must do.

61.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
61.text: She is a fierce ally, and has survived great torments and challenges already. We would be fortunate to have her with us until the end.

105.speaker: Player
105.text: It's not like you to be sentimental.

366.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
366.text: It is not sentimental to appreciate a warrior's strength, or a companion's courage.

202.speaker: Player
202.text: Good riddance. We'll be better off without her.

48.speaker: Player
48.text: There's still hope that we'll find a way to fix her heart.

278.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
278.text: Hope lives in the imagination. I prefer to deal in reality, and in our reality, Karlach is dying.

76.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
76.text: It is better to accept that, and to make sure she is ready to fight to the last.

123.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
123.text: Unnerving though it is, if we are to face an elder brain, we could have no better ally than an illithid.

269.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
269.text: The Emperor is the reason we have made it this far, and if the gith prince's suffering is the price of our survival, so be it.

126.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
126.text: It is sad to see how Jaheira has neglected her family. They should be prepared for the battle that is coming, or they may not survive it.
126.context: NodeContext: after meeting Jaheira;s family - Minthara is concerned the youths are not prepared for war

50.speaker: Player
50.text: Distancing them from the conflict is the best way to ensure they live long lives.

80.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
80.text: If any child of mine spoke of me as disrespectfully as Jaheira's offspring speak of her, their lives would be exceedingly short.

151.speaker: Player
151.text: She's spent her life in conflict - it's natural she wants to protect them from that.
151.context: NodeContext: first phrase is the core of her philosophy. She truly believes this

403.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
403.text: Life is conflict. Coddling children, and denying them that truth only makes them weak.
403.context: NodeContext: first phrase is the core of her philosophy. She truly believes this

124.speaker: Player
124.text: You're right. They should be ready to fight.

71.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
71.text: My mother taught me to talk, to walk, and then to kill. I still hope to thank her by teaching her how to die one day.

111.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
111.text: All things considered, my relationship with her may not be the best model to follow.
111.context: NodeContext: awkwardly acknowledging the dysfunctional nature of her relationship with her mother. Can see the humour in it.

128.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
128.text: Gothic. Decadent. Vulgar. This place clearly had quite the influence on Astarion's tastes.

129.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
129.text: I had thought Cazador little more than a decadent slave-driver and stalker of the night.

130.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
130.text: This is it. The end of everything - or our moment of triumph.

133.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
133.text: Patricide is often the first step toward greatness, but I hope Wyll does not regret sacrificing his infernal powers.
133.context: NodeContext: Wyll killed his father. Minthara sees the bright side in her evil way.She is very sincere about this.

135.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
135.text: No matter how desperate the fight becomes, stay the course. We will not fail. We will dominate.
135.context: NodeContext: Determined, confident, reassuring her allies in a dark moment

140.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
140.text: Myrkul, Bane, Bhaal, and now Shar? Are there any gods who do not want the Prism?
140.context: NodeContext: listing off gods who are hunting the party, slightly bewildered but ready to take on all of them

54.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
54.text: No matter - they will all be disappointed. Lord Ao the Overgod could not take it from us.

142.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
142.text: Bhaal should be begging me to join his ranks.

143.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
143.text: I was unsure of our alliance with the Sharrans - betraying Shadowheart seemed a steep price to pay - but I accept the wisdom of it now.

337.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
337.text: Despite my antipathy to Viconia, I am sure she will aid us when the time comes.
337.context: NodeContext: Viconia is a fellow drow from the same city as Minthara, they don't know each other well, but Minthara dislikes her

73.speaker: Player
73.text: What do you have against Viconia?

334.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
334.text: Two hundred years ago, she disgraced her family - the DeVirs - by refusing to obey a divine order from Lolth.

23.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
23.text: It was quite the scandal, and I was young enough that it left an impression on me.

397.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
397.text: I admire those who challenge authority, but Viconia fled from her troubles rather than facing them.

2.speaker: Player
2.text: You and Viconia don't seem all that different.

383.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
383.text: You insult me. Viconia left the Underdark to rule a clergy of mournful waifs, and peddlers of secrets. I have far grander ambitions.

198.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
198.text: I do not mean to diminish her achievements entirely though.

4.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
4.text: She has been exiled from the Underdark for more than a century. She would not have survived if she were not willing to fight.

219.speaker: Player
219.text: I'm not convinced she will help. She's hardly trustworthy.

343.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
343.text: If she were here, Shadowheart would remind you that we are hardly trustworthy ourselves.

25.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
25.text: We do not need to trust Viconia, we only need to know which side she will take in this conflict, and that is clear.

18.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
18.text: She will take our side because it best protects her interests.

150.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
150.text: Neither the Zhentarim or the Guild are capable of running this city as they should.
150.context: NodeContext: superiority complex kicking into high gear as she assesses the chriminal organisations that run the city

368.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
368.text: Once we have conquered the Absolute, perhaps we can turn our attention to dissolving the criminal elements of Baldur's Gate, and replacing them with our own candidates.
368.context: NodeContext: superiority complex kicking into high gear as she assesses the chriminal organisations that run the city

155.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
155.text: Hear me, wizard. You cannot go through with Elminster's ludicrous plan.
155.context: NodeContext: speaking to Gale, annoyed with him

276.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
276.text: Destroying the Absolute before we fully understand it would be madness.

391.speaker: Player
391.text: If it is Mystra's will, I must obey.

215.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
215.text: To serve the gods is always a choice, and to martyr oneself for them is insanity.

60.speaker: Player
60.text: We need to destroy the Absolute, no matter what it is.
60.context: NodeContext: trying to reason with Gale

136.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
136.text: You are a wizard, are you not? Surely you have an obligation to learn about the world and all of its mysteries rather than destroying them.
136.context: NodeContext: trying to reason with Gale

36.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
36.text: I'm glad you see reason. To martyr oneself for the fickle gods is insanity.

83.speaker: Player
83.text: Your concern is for the Absolute rather than me. Touching.

179.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
179.text: You are welcome to explode wherever and whenever you please, as long as you do not destroy anything of value.

157.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
157.text: I, for one, will miss the shadow curse. For all the pain it caused us, it did at least obscure the incessant sun.
157.context: NodeContext: not entirely serious, but she is bitter about the 'incessant sun'. She has delicate skin!

165.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
165.text: This place is wondrous. A shame it is not ours to command.
165.context: NodeContext: inside a factory producing military machines, admiring

170.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
170.text: I must ask you something. First, let me make it clear that I do not object to the killing of Isobel, or the loss of Last Light.

47.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
47.text: But I do not understand why you killed the cleric.

96.speaker: Player
96.text: I was ordered to. By my butler.
96.context: NodeContext: concerned and a little bemused

163.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
163.text: Sometimes I think you are quite mad. Other times I think you still hold on to a slim fragment of your sanity.
163.context: NodeContext: concerned and a little bemused

369.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
369.text: I will be watching you - and watching for this 'butler' of yours as well.
369.context: NodeContext: concerned and a little bemused

384.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
384.text: We paid the price for your thrills when the shadows surrounded us. If you must kill for the pleasure of it, select your targets more carefully.

386.speaker: Player
386.text: Isobel and the Harpers would have realised we're a threat to them eventually.

264.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
264.text: I would prefer if you informed me of your intentions before striking in future.

101.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
101.text: I prefer strategy to instincts and impulses.

42.speaker: Player
42.text: Her death will yield me a great reward.

300.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
300.text: I see. The end does justify the means. Be that as it may...

172.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
172.text: We face a threat capable of eradicating this city - capable of eradicating us with a thought.
172.context: CinematicNodeContext: walks away from the party in disgust

357.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
357.text: Your father - the Lord of Murder - offered you all of the powers of death and carnage. Powers that we will need before this fight is through.
357.context: CinematicNodeContext: walks away from the party in disgust

281.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
281.text: And instead you have chosen to sever yourself from the legacy of blood that was your inheritance.
281.context: CinematicNodeContext: walks away from the party in disgust

382.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
382.text: I was ready to rule by your side, Slayer. But you have given up a most glorious and dishonourable birthright. We are finished.
382.context: CinematicNodeContext: walks away from the party in disgust

113.speaker: Player
113.text: I love you, isn't that a greater power than anything?
113.context: CinematicNodeContext: walks away from the party in disgust

159.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
159.text: You have seen a god reanimate the bones of his Chosen, you have seen an entity capable of commanding legions with a thought.

171.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
171.text: You have seen the fires of the Hells, and the devils who dwell there.

244.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
244.text: If you believe love is a greater power than all of that, you are stupider than I feared.

371.speaker: Player
371.text: You're only alive because I resisted the Urge to snap your neck the first time we lay together.
371.context: CinematicNodeContext: walks away from the party in disgust

94.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
94.text: It would have been a mercy - at least I'd have been spared this drivel.
94.context: CinematicNodeContext: walks away from the party in disgust

91.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
91.text: If you have any strength left, bring it to the battlefield. You certainly do not have enough to share my bed anymore.
91.context: CinematicNodeContext: walks away from the party in disgust

139.speaker: Player
139.text: We're preparing for battle against an elder brain - this isn't the time for melodrama.

148.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
148.text: It is the perfect time for whatever was between us to die.

239.speaker: Player
239.text: This doesn't mean I'm good now, simply that I'm in control.

152.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
152.text: How small-minded. This is not about good or evil - this is about power. You rejected glory, and I reject you.

184.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
184.text: You rejected the extraordinary, and for what?

232.speaker: Player
232.text: It was the only way to gain control of myself.

181.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
181.text: The only reason you ever lost control is because you resisted the truth - rejected the glory of your true self.

145.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
145.text: Bhaal gave you an opportunity to embrace your savage birthright, and to tame it.

16.speaker: Player
16.text: For freedom. Bhaal only wanted me to serve him.

363.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
363.text: The relationship between gods and mortals will always be one of subservience, but you could not hope for a finer master than Bhaal.

85.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
85.text: He gave you an opportunity to embrace your savage birthright and to tame it.

72.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
72.text: Without the promise of your blood, I fear you have lost part of your strength that you can never regain.

242.speaker: Player
242.text: I resisted the god of murder. You should be congratulating me, not complaining.

146.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
146.text: If you need a pat on the head and a scratch behind the ears, I am sure Minsc will provide. Boo has him well-trained.

82.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
82.text: Talk to Jaheira if you wish to hear tales of heroic Bhaalspawn and their past victories. She likes filling peoples' heads with noble ideals.

65.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
65.text: If you want empty platitudes and a rousing, gallant speech, young Wyll Ravengard may be able to provide it.

188.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
188.text: I would prefer to cut your throat, and finish what Bhaal could not.

66.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
66.text: But you may still be effective, even in your diminished state, and we have precious few allies in this battle.

138.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
138.text: If it's congratulations you want, I am sure Karlach will provide. The language may be foul, but the feeling will be fair.

149.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
149.text: If you want mindless praise and affection, find Scratch. He will nuzzle your hand and follow at your heel no matter how disappointing you are.

127.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
127.text: I deal in reality, not idealism, so you will have to seek praise elsewhere.

182.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
182.text: I hope Elminster's message has not left you feeling dejected, wizard. It is better for you to be free of Mystra.

10.speaker: Player
10.text: Strange to say, but you may be right.
10.context: NodeContext: just complimented Gale and is trying to ground him in reality again so he doesn't get too pompous, and so SHE doesn't seem too soft

407.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
407.text: Now, return to your books. We have a city to save, and an elder brain to master.
407.context: NodeContext: just complimented Gale and is trying to ground him in reality again so he doesn't get too pompous, and so SHE doesn't seem too soft

166.speaker: Player
166.text: How is it better? Mystra is magic. I'm nothing without her.
166.context: NodeContext: reverse psychology - she's trying to cheer Gale up

195.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
195.text: Oh? Are you suddenly incapable of touching the weave? Do your spells fizzle before you can cast them? I think not.
195.context: NodeContext: reverse psychology - she's trying to cheer Gale up

55.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
55.text: You are Gale, Wizard of Waterdeep, and with or without Mystra, you are as great a practitioner of magic as anyone I have ever known.

402.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
402.text: There has never been a need to.

156.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
156.text: Now stop sulking and practise your spellcraft. We have a city to save, and an elder brain to master.
156.context: NodeContext: just complimented Gale and is trying to ground him in reality again so he doesn't get too pompous, and so SHE doesn't seem too soft

216.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
216.text: She has made you believe that you need her. That is what the gods do. In truth, she is not so different to the Absolute.

109.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
109.text: She infests your notion of the weave, just as the Absolute's voice infested my thoughts.

40.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
40.text: You will realise, soon, how little you need her. Or you will die, mourning a loss that has no meaning.

222.speaker: Player
222.text: This is none of your business, Minthara. You don't know what you're talking about.

183.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
183.text: Vengeance is a bitter pill for kind souls. I pity Karlach that she could not savour Gortash's death.
183.context: NodeContext: after seeing Karlach break down in tears after getting revenge on Gortash. GEnuinely sad

200.speaker: Player
200.text: It must be hard to savour anything when your time is running out.
200.context: NodeContext: after seeing Karlach break down in tears after getting revenge on Gortash. GEnuinely sad

319.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
319.text: Indeed. When my time comes, I will not go quietly.
319.context: NodeContext: after seeing Karlach break down in tears after getting revenge on Gortash. GEnuinely sad

354.speaker: Player
354.text: It was a great victory - we should all celebrate.
354.context: NodeContext: after seeing Karlach break down in tears after getting revenge on Gortash. GEnuinely sad

224.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
224.text: For her sake, we should not. And besides, celebrations can come later - our fight is not over yet.
224.context: NodeContext: after seeing Karlach break down in tears after getting revenge on Gortash. GEnuinely sad

336.speaker: Player
336.text: She needs to pull herself together. We haven't won this fight yet.

19.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
19.text: She will be ready to right when we need her, I am sure of it.

185.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
185.text: If the devil truly holds an artefact that can free Prince Orpheus, we cannot ignore it. Any ally who can aid us against the brain is worth having.

186.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
186.text: Even when the faithful abandon them, sacred places do not lose their power. Be on your guard.

189.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
189.text: The darkness here reminds me of home - so does the danger. Be on your guard.
189.context: NodeContext: in the shadow-cursed lands. Alert

24.speaker: Player
24.text: Do you have any idea where we'll find Balthazar?
24.context: NodeContext: Bitterly correcting herself with the emphasis on 'infection'. That is the reality that she has recently remembered.

356.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
356.text: Z'rell said we should begin our search at the Thorm Mausoleum. It is north of the House of Healing, deep in the shadows.

38.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
38.text: I would advise a thorough search of Balthazar's chambers at the tower before delving into the mausoleum. Any knowledge we can find may arm us for what is to come.

289.speaker: Player
289.text: The House of Healing might be a good place to scavenge medical supplies.

191.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
191.text: Doubtful. Like everything else in these lands, its original purpose has been corrupted by the shadows.

52.speaker: Player
52.text: Do you know anything about the House of Healing?

58.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
58.text: Something lingers there. Something that inspires terror among those cultists unfortunate enough to have glimpsed it while patrolling the area.

30.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
30.text: They dare not enter. Naturally, anything that frightens them intrigues me. We should investigate.

168.speaker: Player
168.text: Any idea what we should expect to find at the Mausoleum?

251.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
251.text: Ketheric himself was entombed there for decades. An undying man, sealed in darkness with the bones of his ancestors.

335.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
335.text: I would have thought he'd seen enough of the place for several lifetimes, but he still visits on occasion.

364.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
364.text: Perhaps a particle of sentimentality remains in Ketheric, and he mourns for his family. I do not know.

175.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
175.text: But if Balthazar's mission has taken him to the Mausoleum, we will find more there than bones and memories.

106.speaker: Player
106.text: Did you spend much time in these lands when you served the Absolute?
106.context: NodeContext: Bitterly correcting herself with the emphasis on 'infection'. That is the reality that she has recently remembered.

372.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
372.text: No. My indoctrination - my infection - took place at Moonrise, but I did not stay here for long.
372.context: NodeContext: Bitterly correcting herself with the emphasis on 'infection'. That is the reality that she has recently remembered.

299.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
299.text: Some True Souls are not fit to go to war. They act as guards in these lands, or spread the cult's influence through more insidious means than conquest.

253.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
253.text: Ketheric recognised me as a soldier, and took me into his army immediately.

325.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
325.text: First, I fought alongside him, and then I was given a command of my own. That is where we first met.

379.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
379.text: That I was willing - honoured even - to lead a pack of goblins in the Absolute's name is proof enough that I did not know my own mind.

380.speaker: Player
380.text: Strange that the cult gathers its forces in such a hostile place.

34.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
34.text: It is not only a hostile place, it is a hidden place. My family have a saying: Let the first blood you draw be your enemy's end.

193.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
193.text: Ketheric is working from the same principle. He raises his army in shadow so none may know the extent of his power until it is too late to resist.

249.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
249.text: To kill Ketheric, we must strip him of the power that keeps death from claiming him.

122.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
122.text: We know that power has its source in a relic - the Nightsong - and we know that Balthazar was responsible for its creation.

104.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
104.text: He was looking for the Nightsong inside the temple. We should return there and see what we can discover.

90.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
90.text: Allying with that maggot-infested wretch makes my skin crawl, but if he can help us to secure the relic, so be it.

49.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
49.text: We must pick up his trail at the Thorm Mausoleum.

208.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
208.text: The relic Balthazar seeks may be the key to this. He is not only Ketheric's closest advisor, but an accomplished necromancer.

174.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
174.text: The necromancer Balthazar should be our next target.

392.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
392.text: The kind of man who sees death as a problem to solve rather than an inevitable truth.

327.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
327.text: We should return to Moonrise and search his chambers thoroughly - if we can learn anything of the relic there, it may arm us for what is to come.

194.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
194.text: Ah, the wizard. I could not help but notice that you have been exploring new avenues of knowledge recently - I approve.
194.context: NodeContext: opening phrase is a greeting to Gale - she doesn't know his name. He's just 'the wizard'.

28.speaker: Player
28.text: Must you always refer to me as 'the wizard'. My name is Gale.
28.context: NodeContext: it really isn't. She's already forgotten what she was told

271.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
271.context: NodeContext: it really isn't. She's already forgotten what she was told

187.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
187.text: Continue to indulge your curiosity in the pursuit of new power, and I might deign to remember it.

398.speaker: Player
398.text: It is my duty to seek out knowledge, whatever the source.

401.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
401.text: I could not agree more. The pursuit of knowledge and power should always be our goal.

33.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
33.text: Do not let the laws or scruples of inferior minds stand in your way.

92.speaker: Player
92.text: I don't care about your approval.

110.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
110.text: Then we have something in common, wizard, for I do not care about yours.

197.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
197.text: Shadowheart looks different. A change of diet, perhaps?
197.context: NodeContext: Shadowheart has changed her hairstyle. Minthara genuinely doesn't know what's different.

206.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
206.text: Wyll would be wiser to leverage his family name for a position of power in Baldur's Gate. The hells can have him for all I care.
206.context: NodeContext: speaking of Gale, who is turning to the dark side

207.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
207.text: Shar has discarded young Shadowheart like a broken toy. The gods are ever fickle.
207.context: NodeContext: speaking of Gale, who is turning to the dark side

209.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
209.text: The wizard has become slightly less insipid and a little more insidious of late. The change suits him.
209.context: NodeContext: speaking of Gale, who is turning to the dark side

247.speaker: Player
247.text: These new abilities may corrupt him.
247.context: NodeContext: you say potato, I say potahto - but much more sinister of course

211.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
211.context: NodeContext: you say potato, I say potahto - but much more sinister of course

77.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
77.text: I believe we are only beginning to understand what he is capable of.

329.speaker: Player
329.text: I presume you mean Gale? I'm a wizard too, you know.
329.context: NodeContext: she doesn't remember Gale's name - and doesnt' see why she should

376.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
376.text: Yes, but I know your name. His often escapes me.
376.context: NodeContext: she doesn't remember Gale's name - and doesnt' see why she should

237.speaker: Player
237.text: I fear these new powers may corrupt his connection to the weave.

254.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
254.text: I always thought wizards were curious beings. Your attitude is rather dull.

333.speaker: Player
333.text: A wizard should seek out knowledge and power, whatever the source.

353.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
353.text: I agree. It is a wizard's curiosity that drives them to greater heights.

210.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
210.text: I have heard much of the cunning and caution of the Harpers. Clearly those tales were exaggerated.
210.context: NodeContext: surprised by how feeble the harper 'network' is.

227.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
227.text: Their entire network in the city has been infiltrated and undone by a handful of imposters.
227.context: NodeContext: surprised by how feeble the harper 'network' is.

312.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
312.text: Little wonder the surface world is in such disarray if they are among its protectors.
312.context: NodeContext: surprised by how feeble the harper 'network' is.

218.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
218.text: We need to get out of here.

220.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
220.text: Astarion was a powerful ally. It was foolish to sacrifice him for the favour of the craven Gur.

261.speaker: Player
261.context: NodeContext: matter of fact assessment of the situation

46.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
46.text: A monster may be precisely what we need if we are to survive what is coming.
46.context: NodeContext: matter of fact assessment of the situation

35.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
35.context: NodeContext: pragmatic rather than sad, speaking of the loss of Astarion

359.speaker: Player
359.text: It's not for their favour - it was the right thing to do.
359.context: NodeContext: pragmatic rather than sad, speaking of the loss of Astarion

137.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
137.text: I am not opposed to killing an ally who has outlasted their use, but Astarion had become a formidable weapon.
137.context: NodeContext: pragmatic rather than sad, speaking of the loss of Astarion

323.speaker: Player
323.text: I fear you may be right.
323.context: NodeContext: convinced she is always right and stating it as amatter of fact

265.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
265.context: NodeContext: convinced she is always right and stating it as amatter of fact

223.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
223.text: We can trust Karlach to do what is needed, but she must do it quickly.

225.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
225.text: Your past is revealed to us, Chosen of Bhaal. How does it feel, to know who you truly are?

315.speaker: Player
315.text: I don't know - I haven't finished processing it yet.

180.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
180.text: Allow me to process it for you.

120.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
120.text: We believed we were all victims of the cult of the Absolute, but now we learn that one of us was an architect of this grand religious hoax.

262.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
262.text: You helped to create this conspiracy. That means you may be the best person to help us control it, and the key to our victory.

231.speaker: Player
231.text: I want to take back my rightful place.

29.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
29.text: Good. We will both have our vengeance on Orin. All that we need argue about is which one of us has the pleasure of opening her throat.

246.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
246.text: Once she is dead, we can seize control not only the Temple of Bhaal, but the cult of the Absolute as well.

62.speaker: Player
62.text: Disturbing. I'd rather forget my past than embrace it.

178.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
178.text: Are you so afraid that you cannot see what an opportunity this is? You could be our salvation.

226.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
226.text: I had thought Cazador little more than a decadent slave-driver and stalker of the night.

108.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
108.text: This rite of ascendance suggests he is far more impressive and ambitious than I realised.

370.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
370.text: Does your ambition match his, Astarion? You have risen from slavery already - perhaps you can complete your ascension.

263.speaker: Player
263.text: Are you suggesting I perform the rite myself?

399.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
399.text: I am suggesting that you consider the possibility.

125.speaker: Player
125.text: I'm not involving myself with any damned infernal rites.

79.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
79.text: Then you should reacquaint yourself with the taste of rat-blood, since you may well be a spawn again before long.

340.speaker: Player
340.text: I just want Cazador dead. Nothing more.

322.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
322.text: Do not be craven. He stole your life. You deserve more than revenge - you deserve to take everything from him.

41.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
41.text: We must destroy him in his lair before he completes the rite, and becomes a threat not just to Astarion, but to our own designs on the city.

228.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
228.text: Do what must be done. Become illithid, and we can end this.

230.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
230.text: I would live forever if I could. Death is not rest or relief, it is only ever a form of defeat.

272.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
272.text: Whatever her reasons for doing so, Jaheira's choice to keep the scroll shows that she is not ready to give up her fight.

233.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
233.text: Lae'zel was wise to slay the githyanki rebel. We have already angered enough gods, we need not anger Vlaakith as well.

245.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
245.text: Show no mercy. We must cleanse this place.
245.context: NodeContext: preparing for battle, enjoying herself

248.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
248.text: Speak quietly. Shar's agents will be listening.

255.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
255.text: We have attracted Umberlee's wrath. Let us be sure not to take any long sea voyages in the near future.
255.context: NodeContext: closing statement of a quest completed rather than a new adventure - the Umberlee section is done at this point, she's reflecting

256.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
256.text: You feint as well as any matron mother in Menzoberranzan. Let the wizard lie back, and nurse his wounded ambitions.
256.context: NodeContext: trepidation and a little excitement - she's looking forward to killing Ketheric, even though she's frightened of what is to come

352.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
352.text: When Dame Aylin comes for him, I only hope she stays her blade a moment - to let him see his folly in his final breath.

258.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
258.text: Where Ketheric has gone, madness and horror await. Steel yourself - we must follow.
258.context: NodeContext: trepidation and a little excitement - she's looking forward to killing Ketheric, even though she's frightened of what is to come

259.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
259.text: The elder brain is close. Be ready for anything.

260.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
260.text: Lorroakan's the type to cower behind contraptions and cantrips rather than facing danger. He has about as much spine as a grey ooze.

240.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
240.text: Dame Aylin is likely to tear him in half if she learns of his plans. We should tell her immediately.

268.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
268.text: Orpheus believes it is his destiny to prevent the Grand Design. If he is willing to become illithid to do so, who are we to stand in his way?
268.context: NodeContext: malicious - 'our design' is to betray Orpheus and control the Absolute.

308.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
308.text: It does not mean he will be able to stop our design when the moment comes.
308.context: NodeContext: malicious - 'our design' is to betray Orpheus and control the Absolute.

275.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
275.text: It is good to have friends in high places. We should keep the future Grand Duke Ravengard close.

277.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
277.text: The gith god-queen is dreadful to behold. I understand now why Lae'zel admires her.

285.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
285.text: Shadowheart could have been so much more than we have allowed her to be. This was not the time to hold her back.
285.context: NodeContext: slight awe, self-satisfaction at having discovered a mysterious ancient dungeon beneath BAldur's Gate

288.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
288.text: This place is almost untouched by the squalor of the surface. If I ruled this city, this is where I would make my home.
288.context: NodeContext: slight awe, self-satisfaction at having discovered a mysterious ancient dungeon beneath BAldur's Gate

294.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
294.text: This better be important. Every time I open my mouth, I taste the feculence of this place.

297.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
297.text: We were wise to ally ourselves with Gortash. While Orin lives, she is the greatest threat to our survival - we must hunt her down and eliminate her.
297.context: NodeContext: with a smile, she's making fun of her Underdark origins

298.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
298.text: An underground city of villains. It's almost like being home again.
298.context: NodeContext: with a smile, she's making fun of her Underdark origins

301.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
301.text: Murder, oppression, conspiracies. This city has its charms after all.

173.speaker: Player
173.context: NodeContext: DUTH-cloin (rhymes with truth,rjhymes with loin) - a district of Menzoberranzan, Minthara's home city. Literally translates as 'manyfolk', a diverse district.

147.speaker: Player
147.text: There is danger on every corner.
147.context: NodeContext: DUTH-cloin (rhymes with truth,rjhymes with loin) - a district of Menzoberranzan, Minthara's home city. Literally translates as 'manyfolk', a diverse district.

114.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
114.text: My mother visited, during one of her grand tours of the surface world. She claimed the streets were almost as varied and full of danger as those in Duthcloim.
114.context: NodeContext: DUTH-cloin (rhymes with truth,rjhymes with loin) - a district of Menzoberranzan, Minthara's home city. Literally translates as 'manyfolk', a diverse district.

287.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
287.text: I never believed her until now.

296.speaker: Player
296.text: Your idea of charming is very different to mine.

190.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
190.text: If you cannot see the appeal of bloodshed and danger, perhaps you should retire from adventuring and farm root vegetables for the rest of your days.

305.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
305.text: My people tell tales of Minsc and his ferocious hamster Boo to frighten our children.

15.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
15.text: 'Beware loud men with purple scalps and ugly rodents, for they think of you as evil, and will kill you on sight.'
15.context: NodeContext: not putting on an exaggerated voice, but she is quoting a warning from her childhood, told to her by an elder.

131.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
131.text: It is amusing to hear that the Legendary Ranger has become as much a terror in his own city as he is in the Underdark.
131.context: NodeContext: amused - the 'legendary ranger' is minsc

306.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
306.text: Killing one's parents can be an important rite of passage - a usurpation of their place in society.
306.context: NodeContext: genuinely believes this to be true

20.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
20.text: Shadowheart may not have gained status from her parents' death, but she has freed herself from Shar's influence. There is comfort in that.

307.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
307.text: Devils, Dukes and Blades all must, as common people come to dust. Farewell, young Wyll.
307.context: NodeContext: intentional rhyme, Wyll just died, and she's not particularly upset, but notes the occasion nonetheless

316.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
316.text: We must press our advantage while we can. Slaughter every cultist, and clear a path to the rooftop.
316.context: NodeContext: commander giving orders in battle

317.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
317.text: I have rarely dealt with devils, but Raphael does not seem dissimilar to the aristocrats of Menzoberranzan.

283.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
283.text: Like them, he will be true to his word, should we do as he asks, but he will stand to gain more than he gives.

328.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
328.text: What fun I would have if I could play with Wyll as Mizora does.

330.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
330.text: I thought the vampire spawn would have needed an invitation to enter.
330.context: NodeContext: after the camp has been infiltrated by vampire spawn, annoyed to have been caught off-guard

326.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
326.text: That is no excuse for letting my guard down though. We must follow their trail back to Cazador's estate, and save Astarion while there is time.
326.context: NodeContext: after the camp has been infiltrated by vampire spawn, annoyed to have been caught off-guard

273.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
273.text: We should hang up their remains as a warning to Cazador that you are under our protection, Astarion.

243.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
243.text: We should hang up their remains as a warning to Cazador that Astarion is under our protection.

339.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
339.text: If our travelling companions continue to make poor choices, we will soon have every god in this plane and the next hunting us.

134.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
134.text: Lae'zel risks everything with her childish rebellion.

344.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
344.text: Wyll would be wiser to leverage his family name for a position of power in Baldur's Gate than to roam the wilds like some errant ranger.

346.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
346.text: Vengeance can be a bitter pill for a kind soul such as yours, Karlach. I pity you, that you can not savour Gortash's death.

169.speaker: Player
169.text: It's hard to savour anything when your time is running out.

342.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
342.text: Indeed. When my time comes, I do not think I will go quietly. Nor should you.

31.speaker: Player
31.text: Don't get me wrong - I'm glad the fucker is dead. It's just... hard.

293.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
293.text: I understand. If I had been told my death is close, as you have, I would rage.

332.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
332.text: Do as I would. Spend what time remains punishing our enemies.

282.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
282.text: We need your strength to survive what is coming. I vow that you will have mine for as long as you can draw on it.

59.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
59.text: Good. I have little of it to spare.

347.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
347.text: The Crown of Karsus will be ours - the devil cannot have it. We must negate our deal with him by any means possible.
347.context: NodeContext: determined and a little concerned

348.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
348.text: You embrace your illithid self. Good - to deny it is as foolish as denying any other possible advantage, whatever the source.

349.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
349.text: The shadows will take this place eventually, with or without our interference.
349.context: NodeContext: matter of fact - she's not horrofied by the thoughts

350.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
350.text: Shadowheart was a fine cleric, but if her obsession with Shar is more important than the task at hand, we are better off without her.

361.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
361.text: The next urchin that tries to pick my pocket will lose its hand.

257.speaker: Player
257.text: Please don't mutilate any children, Minthara.
257.context: NodeContext: bray-RINN, a district of Menzoberranzan

132.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
132.text: Half of the children here are already mutilated by poverty and starvation.

405.speaker: Player
405.text: You're paranoid. Nobody's trying to pick your pocket.
405.context: NodeContext: bray-RINN, a district of Menzoberranzan

97.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
97.text: Don't be naive. Half of the people here have been greedily eyeing our belongings since we arrived.
97.context: NodeContext: bray-RINN, a district of Menzoberranzan

404.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
404.text: I am reminded of The Braeryn, the Stenchstreets of Menzoberranzan where the sick and the outlawed make their homes.
404.context: NodeContext: bray-RINN, a district of Menzoberranzan

314.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
314.text: Despite the destitution, there is profit and opportunity to be found in such places if one is willing to wade through the squalor.

310.speaker: Player
310.context: NodeContext: with a smile on the first phrase - a sick joke

236.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
236.text: If I take its head, how will it learn from its mistakes?
236.context: NodeContext: with a smile on the first phrase - a sick joke

302.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
302.text: Even here, a child deserves a second chance.
302.context: NodeContext: not spoken with a great deal of sympathy

362.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
362.text: It would have been prudent to ally ourselves with Gortash. While Orin lives, she is the greatest threat to our survival.

367.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
367.text: I had hoped the wizard may be intrigued by the arcane power of the shadow curse, but it seems he rejects it.

117.speaker: Player
117.text: He is wise to reject it, and to seek Mystra's aid instead.

11.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
11.text: Would that be the same Mystra that is responsible for his plight? I am sure she has his best interests at heart.

385.speaker: Player
385.text: I would prefer him to explore the possibilities of the shadow magic.

99.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
99.text: It is frustrating that he is so incurious. I believe he is capable of greater things than he realises.

341.speaker: Player
341.text: I presume you mean Gale? I'm a wizard too, you know.

252.speaker: Player
252.text: He would be unwise to dabble in shadow magic.

161.speaker: Player
161.text: You're right. A wizard should seek out new knowledge and power, whatever the source.

373.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
373.text: Our young cleric would have us believe she has found joy now that her parents are free.

338.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
338.text: I see her grimace when Shar wracks her soul though, and I see the doubt in her eyes as the pain causes her to doubt the path she has taken.

374.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
374.text: Every breath here is painful - do not waste effort on idle words.
374.context: NodeContext: in the shadowfell, a place that drains emotion. The 'pain' is due to that. Not overexaggerated, more an abrupt 'please don't talk right now' than any implied agony.

377.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
377.text: I would live forever if I could. Death is not rest or relief, it is only ever a form of defeat.

267.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
267.text: In destroying the scroll, Jaheira has shown her readiness to give up the fight. We must not follow her example.

378.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
378.text: Raphael can beg for a deal all he wants - the Crown will be ours.

381.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
381.text: Be cautious. The slightest mistake here could cost us our freedom, or our lives.
381.context: NodeContext: quietly but not whispered, spoken in Moonrise, a dangerous place

201.speaker: Player
201.text: Were you indoctrinated in the tower when you first came to the cult?
201.context: NodeContext: cloaker is an underdark creature - it's a familiar phrase to her, like 'as sliippery as an eel'.

266.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
266.text: Not in the tower itself. There is more here than we see, but my mind only holds fragments of my time here.
266.context: NodeContext: cloaker is an underdark creature - it's a familiar phrase to her, like 'as sliippery as an eel'.

27.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
27.text: The memories are as dark and elusive as a cloaker.
27.context: NodeContext: cloaker is an underdark creature - it's a familiar phrase to her, like 'as sliippery as an eel'.

321.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
321.text: His chambers are on the upper level of the tower, but he rarely occupies them.

199.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
199.text: I think he is beyond the need to sleep and dream, just as he is beyond death. His time is occupied in higher matters.

284.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
284.text: When he is not with his troops, he is usually at the rooftop chapel, where he communes with the Absolute, while surveying his army from above.

241.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
241.text: Access is forbidden to all but his closest advisors. Even if we were among them, it would be suicidal to approach him while his power holds.

270.speaker: Player
270.text: Is the Absolute really here, in Moonrise?

56.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
56.text: If not here in the tower, then close by. Surely you can feel its presence too?

212.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
212.text: When I was held in the prison, I felt an overwhelming hunger, as if I were suspended above a great maw, eager to consume and absorb me.

358.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
358.text: That was the Absolute, and I sensed it is powerful enough to swallow the tower whole if it chooses to.

387.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
387.text: You know what must be done. Transform. Evolve.

390.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
390.text: Must we talk? The heat is unbearable - my mouth is as dry as a dust devil.
390.context: NodeContext: no exaggerated coughs or splutters - she's irritated though. Spoken while visiting hell - it's hot!

395.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
395.text: Lae'zel risks our safety. If she attracts the ire of Vlaakith, we will all suffer.

400.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
400.text: It does not surprise me that Shadowheart's faith was based on a lie. Deception is the sum of Shar's design.

406.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
406.text: I am surprised you have time to bother me, wizard. You seem to be spending most of your hours pining after Mystra again.

394.speaker: Player
394.text: Mystra has chosen to bless me for my efforts against the shadow magic in these parts.

176.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
176.text: You would do better to harness the power of that shadow magic than to destroy it.

291.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
291.text: The gods are fickle. Mystra will tire of you again, as she did before.

365.speaker: Player
365.text: It's none of your business what I spend my hours doing.

331.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
331.text: While we travel together, your business is my business.

192.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
192.text: When I see you squandering your talents to serve a god rather than indulging your intellectual curiosity, I cannot help but be disappointed.

213.speaker: Player
213.text: I don't care what you think of me.

318.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
318.text: Then we have something in common.
